Hi Ken - many thanks for your reply.

Good point - I'm not currently doing =
an alternative mutation if the node mutation already exists - but I should.=


In answer to your question - I'm not sure of any *real* advantage of X - =
apart from a conceptual one; I like to model things in the way I think of t=
hem - my Nodes needed equality and position in space seemed to define this =
nicely. (this does make it easier to visualise the expressed phenotype - bu=
t that wasn't a reason). I test-drove my implementation and got quite far w=
ith Node Genes not really performing any value - but eventually I did need =
them and to assign them and Connections Genes innovation-ids I needed to ha=
ve some notion of equality.  I could have used a Node ID.   However there a=
re some nice side effects of position - because I back my genotype up with =
a connectivity map (which amongst other things allows me to make structural=
 mutations without having to search for them) duplicate nodes can not exist=
 implicitly (the connectivity map is keyed on Node).  Also using the positi=
on for Node equality works well for distributed runs (no need for a master =
sequence of IDs shared across the cluster) - although you still need one fo=
r IIDs.  One downside is obviously extra information in the genotype - but =
I haven't seen an issue with this so far - the system is quite efficient at=
 re-using Node Genes and the structural part of Connection Genes regardless=
 of the IID - so maybe there is a saving there.

cheers
Phill

> Hi Phill, assigni=
ng an (x,y) coordinate to nodes is indeed unusual in NEAT.  However, my gue=
ss (without being 100% sure) is that it will not have an overall harmful ef=
fect, so I don't believe it will cause a major problem with the algorithm. =
 However, my main question is what advantage you see for giving nodes an (x=
,y) position?  I'm not sure that it adds anything useful, in particular the=
 x component.  While I do see a role for the y position in identifying recu=
rrence, I am not sure the purpose of x?
> 
> In any case, I don't think the=
 issue of whether adding a new node to a previously disabled connection is =
going to have major consequences regardless of exactly how such a situation=
 is handled.  If you just end up doing nothing in that case (and then perha=
ps trying a different mutation instead) the system should more or less func=
tion without any major problems.

  My implementation seems to run pretty well - although I haven't compared =

> > 
> > Although I treat both Node Genes and Connection =
Genes as innovations for completeness - the system doesn't make use of the =
innovation IDs for nodes - as to me an innovation resulting from a new node=
 is the associated connection innovations created.  Something makes me thin=
k this may be a mistake and I'm missing something.  However a Connection is=
 defined by the two nodes it connects - and a Node is defined by it's posit=
ion in a 0-1 x 0-1 2d space.  This means that nodes are considered the same=
 if they occupy the same space (x,y) - there is no concept of a unique Node=
ID.  When a Node is created during a mutation it is given the X,Y position =
half way between nodes defining the connection it is splitting.  It is poss=
ible that in the future I will add other attributes to Nodes which will be =
taken into account for Node equality too - but for now it is just X,Y.
> > =

 looses this mutation because the new node and connections have already bee=
n added to the genotype in the original mutation.  So all that happens is t=
he connection is disabled - again.  Mat's book mentions this and implies th=
at a new innovation should be created - which i guess means the network end=
s up with an additional node?  I couldn't see where this explicitly happene=
d in Ken's code.
